Award.AwardTitle: TeachEngineering: Expanding and Sustaining Curriculum Access for K-12 Teachers

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
The TeachEngineering (TE) digital library, at the University of Colorado at Boulder, has attained a reputation in the K-12 engineering education community as a high-quality teacher resource of free, classroom-tested, standards-based lessons. As the disseminator of original K-12 engineering curricula from 46 engineering grantees, the collection is accessed by 2.3M users annually, realizing 50% annual growth. The TeachEngineering lessons and activities and the interactive community forums around them support teachers in meeting new engineering-based standards in their classrooms. Attracting more, and more diverse, students to engineering for future occupations and satisfying lives cultivates ambitions in the young while setting the stage for improving and sustaining the nation's economic future. The proposed strategic improvements and user-centered research ensure TeachEngineering's ongoing relevance and sustainability.

The goals of this three-year initiative include making the user experience interactive and community based, expanding collection size and usage, keeping curricula aligned with evolving K-12 STEM standards, modernizing the backend architecture for sustainability and responsiveness, and assessing classroom impact. Activities and approaches include significant expansion of direct involvement of the K-12 teacher community through the design and/or implementation of social, community based and crowdsourced features. The rich new source of information generated by this user involvement will serve to significantly improve the user experience and help index the collection for better and automated search, recommender and standards alignment facilities. Methods to be employed include partnering with the NAE's LinkEngineering community, creation of a far more integrated metamodel of the collection, implementing a model-view-controller framework, and conducting quantitative and qualitative studies on how teachers use TE in the classroom.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The TeachEngineering digital library is a collection of over 1,700 standards-aligned, hands-on engineering lessons, activities and other curricular items for use by K-12 educators to make engineering content, design thinking and engineering habits of mind come alive for K-12 youth.

Broader Impacts

Usage. At grant end, 3.37M unique users had used the TeachEngineering collection in the last year - up 37% YoY - with 7M page views. Usage of the collection changed significantly over the four-year grant, as 222 "how to" confidence building YouTube videos were added to design activities to break down access barriers for K-12 teachers. These videos were viewed 720,952 times in the last year (up 226% YoY) and watch time increased 267% YoY. And, in the last year, 105 new videos were produced and 2,273 YouTube channel subscribers were added.  

User Demographic Shifts. Over the four-year grant, user demographics shifted, as younger, earlier career educators accessed the TeachEngineering collection. By grant end, 29% of annual users were under age 25, with another 31% in the 25-34 year range. Women comprised 60% of users, not surprising given that American elementary teachers are predominantly female. Although 67% of users access the collection via desktop, special attention was paid to system architecture and responsive design to increasingly accommodate curricular access through mobile devices.  

Heaviest per capita usage was in Illinois, closely followed by users from New Jersey, Connecticut, Massachusetts and Georgia. Across the board, educators appreciated the availability of downloadable worksheets, posters, and other educational resources, with 400,000 educational resources downloaded from TeachEngineering in the last six months.

Most users new to TeachEngineering found the collection's contents through organic search, with organic search traffic sessions up 44% YoY. Thus, Search Engine Optimization became increasingly important over the life of the grant as it became much more challenging for users to sort out useful curriculum from the overwhelming noise prevalent in any Internet search experience.

Social Media. The role of social media changed significantly throughout the grant, with the three top sources of user referrals to TeachEngineering in the last year coming from Pinterest, Classroom Google and Facebook, followed by NGSS@NSTA at #4, Teachers Pay Teachers at #7, and YouTube at #9. Although attention to various social platforms is important (and time and resource consuming), the role of social media in overall referrals to the TeachEngineering collection is still relatively low compared to users finding the collection's contents through both organic and direct search.

Intellectual Merit

Broad agreement prevails amongst educators, industry leaders and policymakers that we must vastly improve the teaching of STEM subjects in U.S. K-12 schools. In this technological era, literacy in mathematics, science, engineering and technology is essential for students, and yet our nation faces dire shortages of teachers in critical science and mathematics fields. And, for the most part, engineering - the creation of products and processes that drive our economy - is not part of the everyday language or experience of American youth.

If we are to prepare abundant numbers of students for STEM workplaces, raise the level of scientific, mathematical, engineering and technological literacy in the general population, and enable the U.S. to maintain competitiveness in the global marketplace, we must improve the teaching and learning of these subjects in K-12 schools. As part of reversing a STEM workforce and education shortfall, U.S. educators are struggling to incorporate engineering into K-12 science education, which requires teachers trained in engineering content and pedagogy - skills that differ from how K-12 teachers are prepared. A key strategy to address the STEM education and preparedness crisis is to create a movement of teachers armed with deep content knowledge and pedagogical expertise across the fields of science, technology, engineering and math, who are equipped to teach the design-rich engineering content specified in the Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS).

TeachEngineering's broad (and free) dissemination of engineering-focused STEM curricular resources, coupled with its multiple partnership and outreach initiatives (including CU Teach Engineering teacher preparation and RET professional development), serve society at large by enhancing technological literacy and developing engineering habits of mind among the U.S. citizenry - teachers and students alike.

All curriculum in the TeachEngineering collection are aligned to STEM standards, most notably the NGSS and the Common Core Math standards. Alignment to the NGSS is reported by TeachEngineering  users to be their top motivator for first accessing the collection's curricula, as they seek help in addressing the engineering design component of the NGSS at every level in grades K-12 - even in states that haven't directly adopted (or adapted) the NGSS. Increasing awareness of this teacher need led to realignment of the TeachEngineering collection to a wide range of standards late in the grant cycle, with a special emphasis on engineering design and its natural tie to science learning prevalent throughout the NGSS.
